body: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10061-7 Psychedelics and their non-hallucinogenic analogues were compared, revealing that serotonin 2A receptor (5-HT2AR)-mediated Gi signalling is essential for hallucinogenic effect, with the functional mechanisms underlying this providing insights for designing therapeutic drugs without hallucinogenic effects.

title: Chill out: freezing temperatures produced by letting a stressed alloy relax
summary:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00030-z

A device has been built that relies on a solid-state phenomenon called the elastocaloric effect to produce cooling to temperatures below 0 °C, lower than …
body: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00030-z A device has been built that relies on a solid-state phenomenon called the elastocaloric effect to produce cooling to temperatures below 0 °C, lower than existing room-temperature elastocaloric cooling systems are able to achieve. The innovation demonstrates that elastocaloric technology could offer an alternative to conventional freezing systems that use volatile greenhouse gases.

title: A step towards building miniature human livers
summary:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04012-5

Recapitulating the complexity of human organs in vitro would accelerate drug discovery and enable personalized treatments. By combining different types of…
body: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04012-5 Recapitulating the complexity of human organs in vitro would accelerate drug discovery and enable personalized treatments. By combining different types of liver cell from donor tissues, in vitro models of a liver region that mirror some of the organ’s main structures and functions can be assembled, getting closer to reproducing mini livers in vitro.

title: Scraps of viral DNA in biobank samples reveal secrets of Epstein–Barr virus
summary:
Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00038-5

Viral DNA that is usually dismissed when sequencing the human genome could help to uncover useful information about complex diseases.
body: Nature, Published online: 28 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00038-5 Viral DNA that is usually dismissed when sequencing the human genome could help to uncover useful information about complex diseases.
